content: Can someone have another look at #10350? It's opened since some time now, and I think I made all the suggested modifications.
LGTM. @Eric Wieser shall we merge?
Added a few comments, will let you make the call
Given we have docs#quadratic_form.discr, should we abbreviate to discr here too?
I think discr is short and descriptive. @Riccardo Brasca do you agree?
I agree.
And indeed it seems unusual to use the namespace, I am modifying it.
Done
Is there any link to be made between your discr and the existing docs#quadratic_form.discr, or the the concepts unrelated?
(not that such a link needs to be in that PR)

Riccardo Brasca said:

Done

Doesn't look like you pushed
I see it, its commit 9cc4e91.

Eric Wieser said:

Is there any link to be made between your discr and the existing docs#quadratic_form.discr, or the the concepts unrelated?

It's related, but the relation is quite subtle. In practice for a quadratic field the norm is a quadratic form and the discriminant agree (maybe modulo a sign or something like that).

Riccardo Brasca said:

I see it, its commit 9cc4e91.

Oh, I was expecting discriminant to be renamed to discr too
Ops, I am doing it
I also forgot to update the docstring
:ping_pong:
Having a look!
Ah, cache is messed up :sad: I'll continue reviewing once CI is done.
I guess it's my fault, I merged master...
It would have been fine had the changes not spanned so much of the import tree.

A bit too late, but you can go to master, pull the latest commits, run leanproject get-cache. Then come back to the other branch. It works if you manage to get the cache up to the master commit that was merged into the branch you want to review locally

I'm not sure how get-cache works, but I suspect it would also work if you did a hard reset on master to the commit that was merged into the branch. That is, it would download the correct respective cached oleans files. This is useful if you're a bit too late and master has already changed again before your get-cache
(I do this trick when I want to merge master into my branch locally first and do a quick check that nothing will break)
There's never any need to switch branch to get a cache, you can use get-cache --rev origin/master instead
But if you do get-cache --fallback=download-all, it will automatically find appropriate parent commits with a cache
